exemplars_from_sources.content: The National 4 Mathematics Course develops essential numerical and mathematical skills. The Course has three mandatory Units: Expressions and Formulae, Relationships, and Numeracy. A pass in the Added Value Unit is also required. This will take the form of a test. The test will have two question papers, one in which a calculator is not permitted, and one in which a calculator is permitted.
exemplars_from_sources.summary: Official SQA course specification outlining the three mandatory units and the structure of the Added Value Unit test.

canonical_terms.definition: The Added Value Unit is the final assessment for the course and is graded. It consists of two question papers: a non-calculator paper and a calculator paper.
canonical_terms.application: The SoW should build towards the Added Value Unit, with opportunities for revision and practice assessments.

canonical_terms.definition: One of the three mandatory units, focusing on the manipulation of abstract mathematical expressions and the application of formulae.
canonical_terms.application: This unit should be a core component of the SoW.

canonical_terms.definition: One of the three mandatory units, exploring mathematical relationships and their applications in various contexts.
canonical_terms.application: This unit should be a core component of the SoW.

canonical_terms.definition: One of the three mandatory units, developing fundamental numerical skills and their application in real-life situations.
canonical_terms.application: This unit should be a core component of the SoW, with a focus on practical applications.

lesson_starters: Match-up game with algebraic expressions and word-based descriptions.
What's the rule? activity with a table of input and output values.
cfu_variety_examples: Exit tickets with short questions to gauge understanding.
Peer assessment of work against a set of criteria.

rubric_shapes.name: Problem-Solving Task Rubric (AVU Style)
criteria: Interpreting the problem and selecting a strategy (2 marks)
Applying mathematical skills and knowledge correctly (3 marks)
Communicating the solution clearly with workings (1 mark)

rubric_shapes.name: Numeracy Project Rubric (Pass/Fail)
criteria: Clear presentation of findings (e.g., in a table or graph)

accessibility_notes.guidance: Use clear and simple language, avoiding jargon where possible. Explain mathematical terms in a straightforward way.
Use a dyslexia-friendly font (e.g., Arial, Comic Sans) and a clear layout. Use multi-sensory teaching methods, such as hands-on activities and visual aids.

calculator_topics: Area and volume of complex shapes
calculator_policy.notes: The Added Value Unit has a non-calculator paper (20 minutes) and a calculator-permitted paper (40 minutes).

sequencing_principles: Start with Expressions and Formulae to build foundational skills.
Integrate Numeracy throughout the course to provide real-world context.
Teach Relationships after Expressions and Formulae, as it builds on those concepts.
sow_construction.unit_breakdown_example: The SoW should be structured around the three mandatory units: Expressions and Formulae, Relationships, and Numeracy. Each unit can be broken down into smaller topics.
sow_construction.duration_estimates: The recommended total time allocation for the course is 160 hours. This should be divided between the three units, with time for revision and the Added Value Unit.
context_hooks: Planning a trip on ScotRail or First Bus.
Calculating the cost of a day out at a Scottish landmark, such as Edinburgh Castle or Loch Lomond.
Using data from the Scottish Government website for statistical tasks.

card_design_patterns: Start with a short, engaging starter activity.
Introduce the main concept with clear explanations and worked examples.
Provide opportunities for students to practice the new skill through a variety of activities.
End with a plenary or exit ticket to assess understanding.
lesson_construction.recommended_cfu_mix: A mix of individual work (worksheets), group work (projects), and whole-class activities (mini-whiteboards) is recommended.
lesson_construction.misconception_handling: Address common misconceptions directly and provide targeted support to students who are struggling.
engagement_tips: Use real-world examples and contexts that are relevant to students' lives.
Incorporate technology, such as online quizzes and interactive whiteboards.
Use a variety of teaching methods to cater to different learning styles.

However, the SQA documentation provides a clear and comprehensive outline of the curriculum.
